newsitem.title: CHINA: China's B share markets split on HK handover.
newsitem.headline: China's B share markets split on HK handover.

text.p: China's foreign currency B share markets on Friday offered different views on the return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule with Shanghai bracing for negative news and Shenzhen optimistic, brokers said.
The split reflected investor uncertainty over the direction of China's stock markets after the handover, which fed a frenzy of share buying earlier this year, they said.
Domestic currency A share markets in both Shanghai and Shenzhen fell sharply on expectations that Beijing will take further steps to crack down on speculation, brokers said.
Shanghai's B index was dragged down by speculation that negative news on market regulation will emerge after the return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule, which takes place at midnight on Monday.
But Shenzhen B shares ended up on a rebound ahead of the holiday for the Hong Kong handover, due to institutional buying of companies expected to post good 1997 interim results.
China's markets will be closed on Monday and Tuesday for a holiday to mark the Hong Kong handover.
The Shanghai B index was dragged down by a sharp decline in the A share market as well as uncertainty over the market's direction after the handover.
The B index fell 0.651 points or 0.79 percent to 81.478 points on volume of 19.669 million shares worth $10.845 million, compared with around $16.4 million on Thursday.

"The major positive factor (the Hong Kong handover) which boosted the market for half a year has faded, and technical charts showed a weak short-term outlook, resulting in today's falls," a local broker said.
Of 45 B shares, 42 traded with 25 down, 14 up and three flat.
B share companies expected to report poor interim results for the first half of 1997 in July and August rounded out the list of biggest losers on Friday, brokers said.
Shanghai's A share market was hit by rumours Beijing plans to allow part of China's government and institutional shares, which are not traded, to list on the stock market, they said.
The China Securities Regulatory Commission, the market watchdog, denied knowledge of an announcement on the matter.
Shanghai's A share index plunged 36.421 points or 2.71 percent to 1,306.778 points on volume of 530.587 million shares worth 8.3 billion yuan.
Meanwhile, Shenzhen's B index rose 0.91 points or 0.63 percent to end at 144.72 after losses for four straight sessions. Turnover expanded to HK$106 million from Thursday's HK$67 million.
"Buying was focused on counters expected to post strong 1997 interim earnings, which boosted the B share index," said Cheng Li, an analyst at China Guotai Securities.

Analysts said they expected most listed firms to report slightly better first-half results this year with the effect of last year's two interest rate cuts flowing through to the 1997 interim results. The Shenzhen A share market dipped 10.66 points or 2.32 percent to 449.42 on turnover of 11.5 billion yuan as investors pulled out amid concerns that Beijing may introduce fresh anti-speculative measures in July, brokers said.
